text: About this series: The climate crisis is intensifying humanitarian emergencies around the world and
label: BODY

text: humanitarians are increasingly having to incorporate climate data and forecasts into their analysis
label: BODY

text: and planning. This guidance series has been developed to help humanitarians to access, analyze and
label: BODY

text: interpret common types of climate and weather data, and to provide a common language for working
label: BODY

text: •	 Precipitation forecasts predict how much it will rain during a period of time in the future.
label: BODY

text: •	 Precipitation forecasts can be presented in different ways, such as the total amount of
label: BODY

text: precipitation expected, the likelihood of precipitation occurring, or whether precipitation is
label: BODY

text: expected to be above, below, or near average.
label: BODY

text: •	 The accuracy of a precipitation forecast depends on various factors, such as the presence
label: BODY

text: of El Niño or La Niña events, which can have a significant impact on precipitation patterns
label: BODY

text: •	 Seasonal forecasts offer valuable insights into precipitation patterns over large geographic
label: BODY

text: regions but they may not provide sufficient detail to accurately predict what will happen in
label: BODY

text: smaller areas, such as cities, or during shorter time frames, such as weeks.
label: BODY

text: •	 Medium- or short-range forecasts are able to provide more granular and specific information
label: BODY

text: about expected precipitation amounts and patterns in a particular location over a shorter
label: BODY

text: Precipitation forecasts are predictions of how much it will rain during a specific future period,
label: BODY

text: referred to as the forecast or target period. The forecast period varies in duration, depending
label: BODY

text: on the type of forecast. For example, the forecast period for a short-range forecast could be
label: BODY

text: a day or week whereas the forecast period for a long-range forecast may be as long as three
label: BODY

text: months. The time between the forecast publication (the issue or base time) and the forecast
label: BODY

text: period is called the lead time2. Precipitation forecasts are updated regularly and the updates
label: BODY

text: become more frequent as the forecast period approaches.
label: BODY

text: 1  El Niño events are associated with a warming of the central and eastern tropical Pacific, while La Niña events are the reverse, with a sustained
label: BODY

text: cooling of these same areas. Both events alter weather around the world https://www.climate.gov/news-features/blogs/enso/how-enso-leads-
label: BODY

text: 2 Forecast providers define categories differently. Before using a forecast, always look for the provider’s definitions and/or the forecast and issue
label: BODY

text: Precipitation forecasts make predictions about the likelihood and/or amount of rainfall and
label: BODY

text: are valuable for a variety of applications. Daily forecasts can help determine whether it’s likely
label: BODY

text: to rain during an event, while weekly or monthly forecasts can indicate whether there will be
label: BODY

text: enough rain to begin planting crops. Seasonal forecasts are useful for determining whether the
label: BODY

text: upcoming rainy season will bring more or less rainfall than usual, which can be important for
label: BODY

text: When selecting a precipitation forecast, it is crucial to consider the forecast’s temporal and
label: BODY

text: spatial resolution. Spatial and temporal resolution vary depending on forecast type (e.g.,
label: BODY

text: monthly) and provider (e.g., the United Kingdom Meteorological Office). Providers will typically
label: BODY

text: publish the resolutions of their products and information about how well their forecasts
label: BODY

text: perform in historical cases alongside their forecasts. Understanding the level of detail and
label: BODY

text: accuracy provided by different forecast types and providers enables individuals to assess the
label: BODY

text: reliability and applicability of the forecasts for specific temporal and geographic contexts.
label: BODY

text: Temporal resolution is the shortest unit of time for which the forecast produces a prediction.
label: HH1

text: A seasonal forecast typically has a three-month resolution, whereas a weather forecast might
label: BODY

text: have an hourly resolution. The temporal resolution may coincide with the forecast period, as
label: BODY

text: is the case for seasonal forecasts, or be shorter, as in the case of daily forecasts with an hourly
label: BODY

text: Spatial resolution is the smallest unit of space for which the forecast produces a prediction.
label: HH1

text: Visually, a forecast is presented as a grid, which is made up of individual squares called pixels
label: BODY

text: (also referred to as grid points or cells). Each pixel represents a discrete area of land. The size
label: BODY

text: of that area is the forecast’s spatial resolution. For example, if one pixel covers one hundred
label: BODY

text: square kilometers then the spatial resolution is 10 kilometers. A higher resolution means that a
label: BODY

text: pixel covers more geographic detail over a smaller area, which often comes at the cost of lower
label: BODY

text: temporal resolution or a shorter lead time for the forecast.
label: BODY

text: When assessing how informative a precipitation forecast will be, there are two considerations
label: BODY

text: 1.	 Forecasts become more detailed as lead times shorten. To enable forecasting at longer
label: HH1

text: lead times, climate scientists look at large-scale phenomena that evolve slowly. These
label: BODY

text: phenomena make it possible to produce long-term forecasts that track patterns across
label: BODY

text: large geographic areas and over long timescales. As the forecast period draws nearer, more
label: BODY

text: details become available on when and where it is likely to rain. In other words, as the lead
label: BODY

text: times shorten, predictions become more precise at a higher resolution.
label: BODY

text: 2.	 Forecasts have greater certainty at shorter lead times. When lead times are shorter,
label: HH1

text: there is less time for climate and weather systems to change drastically between the
label: BODY

text: forecast publication and the forecast period. While forecasts with longer lead times are
label: BODY

text: inherently more uncertain they still provide actionable information and are a significant
label: BODY

text: improvement over having no information or relying solely on historical data.
label: BODY

text: When using a precipitation forecast, it is important to remember that conclusions cannot be
label: BODY

text: drawn about rainfall patterns within a forecast’s temporal and spatial resolution. For example,
label: BODY

text: a seasonal forecast with a three-month temporal resolution cannot provide information on the
label: BODY

text: number of rainy days to expect during that three-month period as this would require a forecast
label: BODY

text: with a one day temporal resolution. Similarly a seasonal forecast with a spatial resolution of 10
label: BODY

text: kilometers cannot provide information about the expected rainfall for areas smaller than that.
label: BODY

text: Additionally, it is not advisable to draw conclusions based on a prediction at the level of a
label: BODY

text: single pixel, especially if adjacent pixels indicate variability in the prediction. For instance, if
label: BODY

text: a seasonal forecast predicts above-average rainfall for a pixel at the heart of the city but the
label: BODY

text: pixels covering the rest of the city suggest below-average rainfall, the forecast is less confident
label: BODY

text: in its prediction for the city and may change before it can converge on a reliable prediction.
label: BODY

text: Predictions that are consistent across adjacent pixels signal that a forecast is more confident
label: BODY

text: The minimum number of consistent pixels for reliable predictions depends on several factors
label: BODY

text: including geographic location, time of year, and spatial resolution. However, as a rule of thumb,
label: BODY

text: we recommend no less than five consistent pixels for a reliable prediction when using long-
label: BODY

text: range, seasonal, monthly, extended, or sub-seasonal forecasts of a typical spatial resolution
label: BODY

text: (for more details, see the table below). It is always advisable to consult the forecast provider for
label: BODY

text: There are three types of precipitation forecasts: seasonal forecasts (1-6 months ahead), sub-
label: BODY

text: seasonal forecasts (approximately 2-6 weeks ahead), and weather forecasts that are medium
label: BODY

text: range (3-15 days ahead) or short range (1 hour to 3 days ahead). More details are provided
label: BODY

text: 1.	 Seasonal forecasts (1-6 months ahead) are based on slowly varying, very large-scale
label: HH1

text: climate phenomena such as the El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) and the Indian Ocean
label: BODY

text: Dipole, which have been shown to impact climate conditions worldwide. Seasonal forecasts
label: BODY

text: are produced by global centers, as well as regional and national meteorological offices, and
label: BODY

text: they provide information on whether an area is more likely to experience above-, near-,
label: BODY

text: or below-normal rainfall over a forecasted period of up to three months. While seasonal
label: BODY

text: forecasts can be used to better understand likely trends over the course of a season, they
label: BODY

text: cannot capture weather extremes such as heavy rain events and dry spells or provide
label: BODY

text: 2.	 Sub-seasonal forecasts (approximately 2-6 weeks ahead) are high-resolution forecasts
label: HH1

text: that typically cover a time frame ranging from about two to six weeks. Sometimes they are
label: BODY

text: also described as monthly forecasts. Sub-seasonal forecasts help to bridge the information
label: BODY

text: gap between short-term weather forecasts and longer-term seasonal forecasts. However,
label: BODY

text: producing accurate and reliable predictions for this time frame has historically been
label: BODY

text: challenging due to the complex dependency on both local weather conditions and global
label: BODY

text: climate patterns. In recent years, sub-seasonal forecasts have become more reliable and it’s
label: BODY

text: where we’ll most likely see further improvements in the future.
label: BODY

text: 3.	 Weather forecasts that are medium range (3-15 days ahead) and short range (1 hour
label: HH1

text: to 3 days ahead) often come from national meteorological and hydrological services and
label: BODY

text: typically cover smaller geographic areas at a higher level of temporal detail. They are crucial
label: BODY

text: for responding to sudden onset events such as heavy rainfall or dry spells.
label: BODY

text: 3   Sub-seasonal forecasts are recent products still in research and development. Monthly forecasts can be categorized with seasonal forecasts due to
label: BODY

text: 4   Rainy season onset is defined specifically for the local context and may require meeting several criteria. A forecast may inform on whether there
label: BODY

text: will be rainfall and when, but is not enough to confirm season onset. For example, a definition might be ‘the first day of the wet season is when a wet
label: BODY

text: spell of accumulated rainfall in 3 consecutive days is at least 20 millimeters and there is no dryspell of at least 7 days in the next 21 days’. See more:
label: BODY

text: Precipitation forecasts differ in their reporting methods for predictions. Some forecasts
label: BODY

text: present predictions as the total amount of rainfall in millimeters, while others indicate whether
label: BODY

text: the precipitation is expected to be above average, average, or below average. Additionally,
label: BODY

text: forecasts may provide information on the expected deviation from the average in terms of
label: BODY

text: millimeters, percentage of average, or using an index.
label: BODY

text: To determine how a forecast reports its values, you can refer to the methodology report
label: BODY

text: or summary provided by the data provider. These resources offer insights into the specific
label: BODY

text: reporting approach used by the forecast and enable an accurate interpretation of the
label: BODY

text: Terciles are a statistical concept used to divide a probability distribution into three
label: BODY

text: equal parts. In the context of climate and weather forecasting, terciles are commonly
label: BODY

text: used to categorize the likelihood of different outcomes for a specific variable, such as
label: BODY

text: In a tercile seasonal forecast, there are three possible scenarios for rainfall: above
label: BODY

text: average, average or below average. Under normal conditions, each scenario would be
label: BODY

text: expected to occur one-third of the time. Tercile seasonal forecasts evaluate the state of
label: BODY

text: the climate system at a specific point in time and assess  the likelihood of each scenario
label: BODY

text: When a forecast is issued, it will either report the probability of each scenario or the
label: BODY

text: probability of the most likely scenario. In any case, the combined probabilities of
label: BODY

text: all three scenarios will always add up to 100 percent.The most likely scenario is the
label: BODY

text: category (i.e., above average, average or below average) with the highest probability.
label: BODY

text: The forecast’s certainty increases as the probability deviates from 33 percent, which is
label: BODY

text: the likelihood based on chance alone (one scenario occurring out of three possibilities).
label: BODY

text: Climate science enables forecasts to identify patterns in the climate system that alter
label: BODY

text: the probabilities away from chance. A forecast takes into account multiple pieces of
label: BODY

text: information, each contributing to the likelihood of different scenarios. A probability of
label: BODY

text: 50 percent, indicating a 17 percentage point deviation from chance, signifies that the
label: BODY

text: scenario is significantly more likely to occur. Conversely, a probability of 16 percent,
label: BODY

text: 17 percentage points below chance, indicates that the scenario is significantly less likely.
label: BODY

text: Although a probability of 50 percent may appear low, it represents a significant
label: BODY

text: departure from chance and suggests multiple reasons to expect that the scenario
label: BODY

text: will occur. Probabilities at 40 percent and above are considered likely scenarios,
label: BODY

text: while probabilities exceeding 55 percent are infrequent and indicate highly confident
label: BODY

text: The seasonal forecast above from the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather
label: BODY

text: Forecasts (ECMWF) is an example of a forecast where the most-likely scenario by
label: BODY

text: geographic area is being reported using probabilities. In this forecast, the most-likely
label: BODY

text: scenario is expressed as a percentage and visualized as a single color on the map.
label: BODY

text: This forecast was issued in May 2023 and refers to the forecast period between June
label: BODY

text: and August 2023 (JJA 2023, following the first letter of each month). The brown color
label: BODY

text: scale represents below average predictions, while green represents above average
label: BODY

text: predictions. The forecast predicts that some countries in Southern and Eastern Africa
label: BODY

text: will likely receive below average rains during this forecast period with a likelihood of
label: BODY

text: 60+ percent. Parts of Northern and Western Africa, on the other hand, are predicted to
label: BODY

text: receive above average rainfall with the likelihood reaching 60 percent.
label: BODY

text: Factors to consider when interpreting precipitation forecasts
label: HH1

text: When interpreting precipitation forecasts, it is important to bear in mind a few general rules
label: BODY

text: and facts that influence how the forecast can be used. However, specific considerations
label: BODY

text: regarding forecast skills may vary depending on the particular application, type of forecasts,
label: BODY

text: and geographical region. It is essential to evaluate these factors on a case-by-case basis.
label: BODY

text: A seasonal forecast released by the ECMWF in May 2023 for the African continent.
label: BODY

text: 1.	 Forecasts vary in their skill, or accuracy, level. Forecast skill quantifies the ability of
label: HH1

text: a forecast to accurately reproduce actual observations. Scientists estimate forecast skill
label: BODY

text: by using different statistical indicators. Forecast skill will vary based on the geographic
label: BODY

text: location, the lead time, the presence of an ENSO event, the month of the year, and a
label: BODY

text: number of other factors. In cases where documentation is inaccessible or incomplete, we
label: BODY

text: advise reaching out to the forecast providers for further information. The first time you
label: BODY

text: use a forecast, consult the forecast provider to confirm that its skill is sufficient for your
label: BODY

text: 2.	 Forecasts evolve over time. A forecast provides a prediction at a given point in time and is
label: H4

text: produced based on the information available at that time. The climate system can suddenly
label: BODY

text: or slowly change and the forecast will change with it.
label: BODY

text: 3.	 Be aware of the spring predictability barrier. This refers to the phenomenon where the
label: HH1

text: skill of forecasts is reduced during the spring in the northern hemisphere. This is because
label: BODY

text: during this time the climate system can change rapidly. After May, large climate patterns
label: BODY

text: stabilize and the ability of forecasts to predict improves. This predictability barrier is an
label: BODY

text: 4.	 Different forecast providers can offer varying predictions. The more convergence
label: HH1

text: there is between forecasts from different providers, the more confidence there is in
label: BODY

text: the predictions. When forecasts offer conflicting predictions, there is less confidence in
label: BODY

text: individual predictions and more time is needed for more reliable patterns and convergence
label: BODY

text: 5.	 Forecasts are probabilistic, meaning there is always a chance that something other
label: HH1

text: than the most likely scenario occurs. Confidence in the predictions is highest when
label: BODY

text: probabilities are very high, the most likely scenario is much more likely than the second
label: BODY

text: most likely scenario, the forecast period is close, or a strong ENSO is present. Sound
label: BODY

text: decisions can be made based on forecasts but their uncertainty is the price we pay for
label: BODY

text: obtaining information about events before they occur. The key to using forecasts effectively
label: BODY

text: is to balance the trade-offs between lead time and the ability to act early while mitigating
label: BODY

text: the risk that a less likely scenario occurs.
label: BODY

text: Common errors and misconceptions when using forecasts
label: HH1

text: The following are some of the most common errors and misconceptions that arise when using
label: BODY

text: forecasts, which lead to misunderstandings and ineffective decision-making:
label: BODY

text: 1.	 A high probability is not the same as certainty. A high probability for the most-likely
label: BODY

text: scenario does not mean that the most-likely scenario will happen. It is important to keep in
label: BODY

text: mind that any of the scenarios could happen.
label: BODY

text: 2.	 When using seasonal forecast maps that show the likelihood of a scenario (such as the
label: BODY

text: ECMWF map above), the darker colors usually refer to a higher probability for that scenario.
label: BODY

text: A higher probability does not mean a higher amount of total rainfall.
label: BODY

text: 3.	 Seasonal forecasts do not provide predictions that are granular enough to know what is or
label: BODY

text: is not likely to happen in small geographic areas or during shorter periods of time such as
label: BODY

text: •	 Watch the UK Met Office video series5 ‘Seasonal Forecasts Explained’.
label: BODY

text: •	 Learn more about and access IRI’s seasonal precipitation forecasts.6
label: BODY

text: •	 Download and process seasonal forecasts using Python code in the Centre’s tool AnticiPy.8
label: BODY

text: •	 Dive deeper into the science behind long-range forecasts.9

text: This guidance was developed by the OCHA Centre for Humanitarian Data10 with input from
label: BODY

text: Columbia University Climate School11 International Research Institute for Climate and Society12,
label: BODY

text: and the United Kingdom Meteorological Office13.
label: BODY

text: 4.	 A ‘below average season’ can still receive heavy rain on certain days or light rain on most
label: BODY

text: days because below average refers to the cumulative amount of rainfall over the entire
label: BODY

text: period. Likewise, an ‘above average season’ can still mean that there are frequent dry days
label: BODY

text: 5.	 Below or above average does not provide an indication of how far from average the total
label: BODY

text: 6.	 Above average rainfall does not necessarily mean there is a higher likelihood of flooding.
label: BODY
